Posts.Content: Feb 20, 2013 11:25PM petjunkie wrote: I am getting my port replaced on Friday. I've had it for 3 years and it has always taken acrobatics to get a blood return. Finally, it stopped all together. Of course it worked fine during the dye study! I am lucky that I'm switching treatments so I have had two weeks of no chemo at all, then just today am starting TDM-1. I'm in a pretty good place in terms of infection risk. My onc told me to up the protein as much as possible to help the area heal. Can't hurt to try that!
Posts.Title: Port problems OBXK OBXK

Posts.Content: Jan 17, 2014 04:52PM petjunkie wrote: I was on Zometa for almost 3 years, then we switched to Xgeva which I have been on over a year. I just renegotiated with my onc to do Xgeva every 6 weeks instead of every 4. That way, it lines up with my TDM-1 that I get every 3 weeks, so I don't have to make extra trips to the cancer center. Of course if there is progression in bone mets, we'll go back to every 4 weeks. I'm 39 and worry about fractures after being on these bone builders over 4 years now. I am trying to be careful about getting lots of calcium and I have a bone density test yearly. Have to say I don't run and have never been a runner, but I know that weight-bearing exercise like walking and running are good for your bones. Maybe you could try doing some alternative activities once in awhile like nordic walking (with poles), treadmill walking on super high incline so you still get those endorphins going, etc. There is a lady at my gym's pool that "runs" in the shallow end and tells me it's not as hard on her arthritis. Good for you for keeping up with exercise, which is so great for keeping your body strong, fending off depression, helping with sleep, etc. I am far too lazy and need to get motivated just to get out and walk! I hope you can find a way to keep running without increased fractures. Does surface make a difference? I used to walk at a gym that had a really springy, level track made out of recycled tires or something.
Posts.Title: How often should I take Zometa? Springlakegirl Springlakegirl

Posts.Content: Jun 23, 2010 12:21AM petjunkie wrote: I'm not an expert, but did some research on SUV when reading my first PET scan report. The SUV uptake numbers can range from 0-15. The higher the number, the more the area is "active." My liver lesions were at 14, which was bad. Now they are at 6-7, which is much better. Your numbers are quite low.  So SUV uptake just shows how active the area is-- how much of the radioactive material went to that spot. It does not necessarily mean cancer-- areas of arthritis or scar tissue or areas healing from radiation will also "light up" and have SUV numbers. Because the areas of uptake on your report are a head and a joint, I would think there is a strong possibility for arthritis or just regular bone degeneration that happens in our joints as we age.  Of course, this is why you need your onc to look at the report and interpret it. I'm no doc, but I am hopeful and sending good thoughts your way!

Posts.Content: Mar 22, 2013 05:44PM petjunkie wrote: Hi all, just checking in. Had my second round of TDM-1, all seems to be going well. I had my new port placed just a few days after infusion, so I had a few days of feeling really crummy and sleeping constantly, but I think that was from the port surgery. I haven't noticed any major side effects that I could pin on the TDM-1. Some cramps in my feet. Constant thirst. But who knows what that is from. Hope everyone else is doing well, too. I'm actually looking forward to my third dose because I don't have any other procedures, so I'll be able to see what the few days after infusion are like and can see what just TDM-1 side effects for me might be. I know you all understand when I say that I'm ready to figure out exactly what my new "normal" is, get into a routine with things, and start making plans for travel and fun stuff if I can!

Posts.Content: Apr 6, 2013 06:20PM petjunkie wrote: I just had my 3rd dose of T-DM1. What I'm finding is that I have my infusion on Wednesdays and feel fine that day and the next. Friday afternoon I get hit hard by fatigue and nausea. I take a zofran and go to bed-- it's kind of like having the flu. I get the chills, too. Zofran takes care of the nausea, I haven't actually ever vomited or anything. I feel pretty crummy about 48 hours, starting to feel better by Sunday afternoon. And that's it-- totally normal the rest of the time. It's pretty awesome, actually.  First scans were last week, so let's hope the TDM-1 is working!

Posts.Content: Feb 21, 2013 05:38PM petjunkie wrote: I had my first TDM-1 infusion yesterday. Because it is part of a clinical trial, there were a bunch of little requirements that made it go on forever, but other than that it was easy. They did vitals and weight before and after. Ran the infusion over 90 minutes (after this it will be 30). Then I had to be observed for 90 more minutes, have vitals and weight taken again. I guess they do the weight stuff because they are worried about fluid retention? Anyway, all went well and I feel fine so far. I'm getting over a cold so I'm tired from that, but I don't think the TDM-1 has made it worse.

Posts.Content: May 11, 2013 04:38PM petjunkie wrote: I know it's easy to take the worst-case scenario when this is all so scary and depressing. But really, you don't know that Herceptin is a waste. It could be that without it, the cancer would have advanced much more quickly. It could be that combined with another drug, such as the Tykerb others have suggested, it could be boosted to work better. Treating metastatic breast cancer is tricky business and everyone is different-- some drugs will work, others will not. One small met in the lung-- if it is indeed a met-- is hopefully very treatable. Radiation might even be an option.
Posts.Title: Herceptin or Trastuzumab is of no use.:( It's a waste.:( Godsaveus bhd1

Posts.Content: Aug 3, 2010 11:58PM petjunkie wrote: I did not have a lumpectomy, but a piece of my chest wall was removed during my mastectomy to get clear margins. Radiation wasn't in the plans for me since I did the full mastectomy, so I don't know if it had been a lumpectomy if I would have trusted the rads to get it. About two weeks after my surgery, I had radiating pain from a spot on my chest. I could point to it, and when I saw my surgeon for a check-up she said that was the spot where she had removed muscle from the chest wall. It was annoying, burning pain as the nerves regenerated and it lasted about 10 days. I took percocet at night to sleep, but was also recovering from the full mastectomy so it wasn't just from the chest wall. I've had no problems with it since then. Not to scare anyone, but I had DCIS with micromets. Clear lymph nodes. Two years later, I have a Stage IV recurrence with mets to bones and liver. My lymph nodes are still clear, so it's most likely that my cancer spread through the blood vessels into the chest wall. I'm glad my surgeon had taken that piece out and got the clear margins she wanted. I wish it had been enough.
Posts.Title: cutting into chest muscle during lumpectomy KeepingtheFaith KeepingtheFaith

Posts.Content: Nov 14, 2007 01:48AM petjunkie wrote: Hi Heather, I'm so sorry to hear about your mother, and now you have this additional stress. You definitely want to see a breast surgeon-- someone who specializes in surgery on breast tissue. If it is cancer, they'll do a bunch of tests to see how to proceed and you'll have both a breast surgeon and a breast oncologist to help you make those treatment decisions. A breast oncologist is the one who will make decisions about chemotherapy, etc. So your mom's surgeon probably has oncology training specific to ob/gyn surgeries. You could ask him/her because it's possible he/she specializes in women's cancer surgeries and does both breasts and ovaries. The advantage with a breast specialist is that they are totally focused on nothing but breast surgeries-- lumpectomies, mastectomies, etc. Many breast cancer specialty centers have a "team approach." I have a surgeon, and oncologist, and a radiologist who all meet together to discuss my case. The surgeon is fading out now that my mastectomy is done, and the oncologist has moved to the front as we decide about chemo. This site is great-- I also recommend the message boards on the Komen.org website. Karen

Posts.Content: Jun 27, 2012 10:42PM petjunkie wrote: I've had my port almost three years now. Got it done using twilight sedation, which was fine. Went straight upstairs to chemo after, which made for a long day. It felt tender, like a bruise, and my neck was stiff for a few days i think because of the position it was in during the procedure. At my cancer center, they do not use powerports for PET/CT injections. The nuclear medicine tech told me that they don't use it because it spreads the radioactive material or dye too fast and they miss things in the chest area that way. I get a PET&CT every 2-3 months and that's the only time I have to do IVs in the arm. Everything else is done through my power port and it's really easy. Mine shows when I wear v-necks and such, but honestly I just don't care. It's never bothered me at all and I have two scars because my first port had to be replaced. About that-- my first port did not heal correctly. The incision split open and then I got a blood infection through the port. This was at the beginning of my cancer journey and I didn't want to whine or be a bother blah blah blah so I waited too long to tell someone. Got ridiculously sick from the blood infection and had to have the port removed and be in the hospital for 6 days with a PICC line in my arm for IV antibiotics for weeks before I got a new port. So, just keep it clean and if it doesn't seem to be healing, be sure to have someone look at it. Infections like the one I got are very, very rare. It still didn't keep me from wanting that port back!

Posts.Content: Dec 3, 2010 04:32PM petjunkie wrote: Unfortunately, the problem is with the iPad and not something bc.org could fix. The iPad doesn't support entering text on website using rich text, which is what we have here where you can bold, italicize, line break, etc., without knowing html. We have these little icons that are like using MS word or similar-- that is called "rich text."   The iPad does support entering text in HTML mode, which is why there are probably some places where you can input text on other websites. For example, I believe that if you have a blog on blogger.com, you can chose to enter in HTML and it works from the iPad. But if you chose the rich text option, you can't enter any text. I suppose it's possible that bc.org could allow for posting in a HTML mode, but I think that would be a huge programming undertaking. Hopefully, the iPad software will be updated at some point so the safari browser works with rich text.

Posts.Content: Dec 6, 2007 03:27PM petjunkie wrote: I had a right-side mastectomy six weeks ago. The scar tissue underneath the skin extends pretty far in all directions- up to the collar bone, down past the 2nd rib. The majority of my pain is below my incision, on the ribs, on the surgery side. My physical therapist is helping me to try to break down that scar tissue and reduce the swelling. I also had a drain running across this area, on top of the rib bone. It was very irritating at the time and has taken a long time to really heal. That drain was in for almost two weeks, so I think my body might have developed some scar tissue around the tube that is still in there now. Did your surgeon give you a number to call post-op? Mine has a nurse and I was told to call her with any questions or concerns. I think it would be worth calling and at least leaving a message about the pain you are having, just so you can have some peace of mind. Also, take the painkillers if you need them. You should be pain-free and able to rest for as long as you need to!
Posts.Title: rib pain floridadwg mrs_X_Sunneedazee

Posts.Content: Jan 22, 2012 01:56PM petjunkie wrote: Rengeko, I can't tell you enough wonderful things about SCCA and Dr. Gralow. Since you are Stage IV, I think you have different needs than women with earlier stage cancers. SCCA is a treatment center that is part of an alliance-- the Fred Hutchinson Research Center, UW Hospital, and SCCA. With metastatic disease, I strongly urge you to go to SCCA where you will have access to more clinical trials and have doctors that are participating in research and conferences, thus up on all the latest treatment protocols. Swedish is an excellent hospital and would give you great care, but us mets gals are really better off in a place with a research component that is emphasized. I often meet people at SCCA who are there from Alaska, Montana, Oregon, etc.-- it is one of the best cancer centers in the country. I'd put it up there with MD Anderson. I can't give you too much advice about where to live, except to tell you that this is a very expensive place to live overall. Renton and Tukwila are outside the city and would be cheaper, or North of the city there is Shoreline and Lynwood, which are cheaper as well. I have a friend that lives in a trailer in Lynwood, but it's a senior park so I think she gets a pretty good deal. You might find that since having Stage IV breast cancer is considered a disability by social security, you could qualify for a senior/disabled trailer park?

Posts.Content: May 24, 2014 10:03PM petjunkie wrote: So sorry to hear this-- I know how scared you are. I was stage IV over 3 years last summer when they found one brain met pressing on my pituitary stalk. I was able to have gamma knife on that spot and that was it. It has shrunk down very small and we monitor it (and look for other brain mets) by MRI every 3-4 months. I thought that I would be gone in a year, for sure-- that it was the beginning of the end. But my response to gamma knife was amazing and July will be one year post-radiation.  The tools they have now are amazing. I know someone in my support group who has had multiple brain mets over time, gets gamma knife, goes on with her life. I hope they come up with a great treatment plan for you and that it's wildly successful. In the meantime, don't be afraid to ask for anti-anxiety drugs or whatever you need to get through this. I was just plain terrified and would not have been able to sleep or function without medication to help. Karen

Posts.Content: May 11, 2012 03:43PM petjunkie wrote: I'm sorry you didn't get any responses. I rarely come to this forum, I just saw your post in the "Active Threads" list. Please understand that the majority of women here are undergoing treatment for cancer. So it's hard for people to come in here and respond to everyone that is worried but not diagnosed. Generally these people are looking for support that individuals in treatment just don't have to give. There are some wonderful women here (and men) who come into this section and spend lots of time reassuring and helping others. I am thankful for them. I usually find I cannot post on these threads for two reasons, and I bet I'm not alone: 1. I have Stage IV breast cancer which means constant treatment and dealing with death&dying issues. It is selfish, but sometimes when I read some of the threads in this forum they just make me angry. People convinced they have cancer when a doctor has told them the biopsy was benign, people stressing out and worrying when they don't yet have results, people who are just in general in a way better situation than I am. This isn't the case with all posts, of course. But often I just want to scream "Don't freak out before you have to! Go enjoy a day without a diagnosis hanging over your head!" I know that's not fair of me, believe me. That's why sometimes it's just easier to not post at all. 2. I think that for many women worried that they might possibly have breast cancer, hearing from a metastatic patient isn't helpful. My story just makes them more scared. I don't even go to the YSC support group any more because I felt the women were all thinking "I hope what happened to her never happens to me." I don't want to create more stress. Please also keep in mind that there are others in your situation and you might find support actually by posting on their threads. I know there is an advantage to hearing from those with lots of experience-- but meeting others who are waiting for results might be helpful, too. You unfortunately are joining BCO right in the middle of this huge forum change and people are struggling to figure out the new design and features. I think a lot of posts are just getting missed. Once things settle down in a few days, hopefully more posts will be getting replies. I sincerely hope you find the support that you need, both here and with your family/friends.
Posts.Title: Alot of us in this topic forum dont get answers back? djones37 dogeyed

Posts.Content: May 8, 2016 12:25PM petjunkie wrote: Just wanted to welcome you-- I was diagnosed with MBC at age 35, mets to bones and liver, ER/PR- and Her2+, just like you. That was six and a half years ago and I'm still doing well! Taxol kicked my cancer's butt, first round cleared out my liver mets and they have never come back. I just finished several months of Taxotere, Perjeta, and Herceptin. Worked so well that I'm on a break now and am recovering. Over the years the chemo gets harder, your body can get worn down. But I'm still enjoying life, living independently, going on vacations with friends. I hope you have a great response to treatment and many, many Mother's Days in the years ahead!

Posts.Content: Sep 17, 2014 08:20AM petjunkie wrote: I had a wound vac after my DIEP for about 4 weeks. You have to take the machine everywhere, it's in a bag you can carry, then when you're in bed or just sitting around you can plug it in to keep it charged. It was not painful for me at all, though a few times when they changed the dressing it would hurt. I had a visiting nurse that came to my home every other day. The dressing change has to be done by a nurse, it only takes about 10 minutes but they'll turn the machine off, take the adhesive cover off, then there is a sponge-like wedge inside the wound that they replace and then cover it all again. The sponge is attached to a tube, so the wound vac machine puts constant suction on that pulls out the bad stuff and helps the wound heal faster. I have very sensitive skin so the adhesive was hard to have on my skin all of the time, it was itchy and I got little blisters. But it has to stay sterile so they continue to cover it with tagaderm or whatever those sticky sheets are. I wish that I had used a skin protectant from the very beginning-- it's worth asking about. Before they put the wound vac dressing on, they can use a skin prep thing that is like a lotion, let it dry then put the adhesive on top. It won't totally protect the skin forever, but it did help and I wish I'd done it from the start (not after I already had blisters). They definitely should give you painkillers that you can take before the dressing change. I was on oxycodone healing from the entire surgery, I would always take one about 20 minutes before the nurse arrived. Having home healthcare was awesome, I don't know if that is an option for you but ask about it!
Posts.Title: another mri so scared chris1959 208sandy

Posts.Content: Aug 3, 2010 10:51PM petjunkie wrote: I don't know how in the world you all do that much exercise. I'm exhausted so much of the time. And even when I'm on a break from chemo, I know that my body is working hard at fighting all of the cancer mets in my body. And then there is the bone pain from the mets on top of that.  I gained 15 pounds with Taxol, and was already overweight. Now I'm on Herceptin, Zometa, Xeloda, and Tykerb. The SEs mean that I have to eat a low-fiber diet to help control the diarrhea. No raw veggies, but cooked are okay. I'm a vegetarian and don't eat meat or eggs. My diet is not terrible, but I don't get much exercise besides walking my dogs. And even that is slow from the pain on the bottom of my feet. So Jennifer, I am totally with you. It seems unfair that not only do we have Stage IV cancer, but we have to deal with weight gain and skin problems and hot flashes. I am big and bald a sweaty and my cancer is progressing despite treatment and I just want to scream scream scream! And if I hear "You look great! one more time, I really will scream. I know people mean well, but I think when they say it they really mean "You look fat" because they expect cancer patients to be skin and bones, they are always surprised when they see me.

But overall, it's been tolerable and not as bad as I had anticipated. This is my first experience with any kind of chemo (had mastectomy two years ago, then tamoxifen. Was recently diagnosed with recurrence to bones and liver). I have noticed some mini-headaches on the upper left forehead area, but they only last a few minutes.
Posts.Title: Any Weekly Taxol takers? riverview817 AnacortesGirl

Posts.Content: Nov 14, 2014 06:29PM petjunkie wrote: Congrats Denny 123! Awesome news! I have been on Kadcyla for 19 months. The side effects were easy a first, but got worse over time. A few rounds ago we tried lowering the dose, but I continued to have extreme fatigue, bloody noses every day, bloody gums, neuropathy, nausea, etc. My oncologist said my body needed a break. So, just last week we decided to take a break. I'm doing Herceptin now, and getting Faslodex shots. We are going to scan every 2 months (CT on body, MRI of brain). At the first indication my cancer is growing, I'll go back on Kadcycla. Or, we may try Perjeta and Taxotere instead. I am relieved to finally be able to get up and out of the house now. I really felt tied to my bed-- too tired to get up, waking up to gushing nosebleeds every day, sleeping about 20 hours a day. There was very little quality of life there. But I'm also scared. I failed Tamoxifen and Femara and Armidex, so I don't have much hope that Faslodex will do anything. Herceptin alone has not worked for me in the past. I'm trusting my oncologist to keep and eye on things and be ready to start a new plan a soon as I need to. Trying to not worry and enjoy this time of feeling better.
Posts.Title: Who's on Kadcyla/TDM1? Trish03 Denny123

Posts.Content: Jul 3, 2011 08:10AM petjunkie wrote: Stage IV cannot give blood ever, since we are never done with treatment. We also cannot donate organs. You can contact your local hospital or medical school and ask if they have a "willed body" program. This is when your body can be donated for research or use by medical students.
Posts.Title: question about giving blood KentuckyMom petjunkie

Posts.Content: Nov 10, 2007 04:13PM petjunkie wrote: Kate, I had to have these injections and was terrified because of some messages I'd read that said they were so painful. I had my mastectomy 10/24 and they did the node mapping the afternoon before. First they injected the breast to numb it up-- just a little bee-sting like feeling. Did you ever have a biopsy? It's the same numbing medication, for some people it burns a little. Then, the radiologist injected 6ccs of radioactive fluid into my breast. It took about 5 injections around the nipple. I was so surprised that I could not feel a thing-- there was no pain for me at all. The radiologist said that most people do not feel any pain, some do feel burning while getting the injections. The weird part is that the fluid makes the breast all lumpy and squishy. I had to walk around the hallway for an hour, swinging my arm and massaging the breast to get the radioactive material to work its way through the tissue. None of this hurt. After an hour, they took some pictures with a big machine (I just had to lay on a table). They used permanent marker to mark my skin where the first 4 nodes were. Then they put some waterpoof tape over the markings so that I could do my pre-surgery scrub without washing off the markings. That's it-- then I was on my way home. Seriously, I was so nervous about the pain that I threw up on my way to the hospital. But I felt NOTHING other than the sting of the ladacane(sp?) for a few seconds. Since then I've found that most women don't have pain. Some do, though, so you read those stories and it freaks you out. I hope this helps you! Tell the radiologist doing the injections your fears and he/she will talk you through the procedure. I found it easier than both biopsies I'd been through. I'm disappointed your doctor told you it would be painful-- I think they do that just in case, so they can hear you say "it wasn't so bad." They'd rather have you expect something bad and be happy it wasn't.
Posts.Title: Surgery bapnkat melody

Posts.Content: Dec 10, 2015 01:33PM petjunkie wrote: Call a Social Security office and not a lawyer. They will tell you that Metastatic Breast Cancer diagnosis, confirmed by a doctor, is an automatic approval. It has more to do with their outdated stats which say we have 2 years to live, rather than what you are capable of doing. There are about 60 automatic approval diagnoses that SSDI approves automatically and on the fast-track system. Don't believe a lawyer about these things, they want you to go through them so they get some of your $$! Stage IV, you can apply online/over the phone and it takes about 20 minutes. There is no hearing, no meeting with a judge. Artista, you maybe had a difference experience if you have applied and are not Stage IV. Unfortunately, Stage III and below have to go through the regular system, which does question every single thing you are able to do each day (take care of yourself, sit in a chair, etc.) That is just not the case for Stage IV and if you'd like to more, call your local SS office directly. They are actually very helpful and nice people and will explain the process to you.
Posts.Title: If you are not Stage IV but have questions, you may post here chrissyb Olma61

Posts.Content: Dec 9, 2015 02:36PM petjunkie wrote: Getting SSDI is not at all difficult if you are diagnosed Stage IV. Metastatic Breast Cancer is on a list of "fast-track" automatic approvals. I got my approval in about 3 weeks from the date of application. There is still a 6-month waiting period from the last day you worked until SSDI kicks in. There should be a way on the social security website and/or by calling them to ask what your benefits would be. When I worked, I got a yearly update from Social Security that told me the credits I had, what my disability payment would be if I ever needed it, and how many more years I had to work before I could retire (and I was in my early 30s when I got these, I think everyone who works should be getting one). I could set up a login on the SS website and had all of the info.
Posts.Title: If you are not Stage IV but have questions, you may post here chrissyb Olma61

Posts.Content: Jan 18, 2016 09:41AM petjunkie wrote: I have never heard of diarrhea being a symptom of metastasis, especially without other symptoms. If there were mets in the stomach or something, there would be pain and other symptoms. I have liver mets and have researched what happens at the end stages, when the liver is really messed up, and diarrhea is not on the list. Hopefully your doctor will get back to you about the sample, it's more likely you got some kind of norovirus or something like that. Definitely let your doc know it's still happening and I would ask about taking probiotics, too. Be sure to keep hydrated!
Posts.Title: If you are not Stage IV but have questions, you may post here chrissyb Olma61

Posts.Content: May 14, 2012 12:35AM petjunkie wrote: Hi Lynne, We have had some similar treatments-- Femara and other hormonals didn't work for me. I did taxol first, then tried hormonals, then tykerb (on herceptin the whole time, as well as Zometa and now Xgeva). Tykerb and Herceptin together gave me about 4 months of stability that I hadn't expected, I was scheduled to take Tykerb&Xeloda together but we were holding off on the Xeloda a few weeks so I could heal from an ooph. Lo and behold, markers went down so we went with that a few months. So now I'm on Herceptin, Xgeva, Tykerb, and Xeloda. Xeloda is a chemo and there are several threads about it here. It has it's own side effects, but most women do not lose their hair. There are some others that are simiar-- easier chemos, less harsh, more focused on keeping a good quality of life so you can stay on the drugs a long time. I've been on Xeloda a year now and it seems that I might be looking at another change after my next scans. But overall, I've had a good quality of life for the past year. I guess my point is that even if you need to start chemo, it doesn't have to be as bad as the first one you did when they were really trying to hit the cancer hard. They might be able to come up with a combo of drugs that lets you keep up some energy to chase a kid!
Posts.Title: Freaking out a little - - Tykerb (and other) question lynne248 petjunkie

Posts.Content: Feb 5, 2014 07:26PM petjunkie wrote: I have been on TDM-1 almost a year now. I feel pretty normal most of the time. About 2 days after reach infusion I feel run down and a little nauseated. Kinda like I'm getting the flu. The first several rounds it was more severe than it is now. I get tired for a could of days and don't have much of an appetite. I have a little neuropathy in my feet, but that is probably from prior chemo therapies. I seem to have more hot flashes now, even though my ovaries were removed 3 years ago. TDM-1 has worked pretty well for me. I did get a brain met this past summer and did gamma knife and continued with the same drug. Mets in my bones and liver remain stable. They aren't disappearing, but they aren't growing and I have a good quality of life. I don't notice in particular having a dryer mouth, have had no platelet problems at  all. I do have low potassium and sodium now, but not sure that is from the drug.
Posts.Title: Who's on Kadcyla/TDM1? Trish03 Denny123

Posts.Content: May 18, 2015 12:43AM petjunkie wrote: Becs-- I get the same fever a few days after Kadcycla. I get infusion on a Wednesday and by Saturday or Sunday I will be shaking and shivering, teeth chattering, and feeling truly awful. Fever will come and go, up to 103. After 5-8 hours it seems to be over. It is the worst part of the side effects, for sure. My doctor has never heard of this happening to another patient, either.

If my doctor thinks it's reasonable that I even have the possibility of living that long, that's pretty amazing! But weird to wrap my head around, too.

Chemo is not nearly as bad as I thought it would be-- that's just my experience. I hope to be on it for many years to come!

Posts.Content: Mar 23, 2014 10:25AM petjunkie wrote: Nettie,  Bone mets are generally constant pain that does not come and go. A warm bath would probably improve muscular pain by helping the muscles relax. There are tons of small muscles around the spine and ribs that can cause you pain. If you pain is constant (mine feels like a burning spot, like a bruise that is getting pushed on, small areas that I can put a finger on) for more than 2 weeks, you should talk to your doctor. Karen

Posts.Content: May 18, 2010 11:00PM petjunkie wrote: My oncologist gave me zantac to take every day. When that wasn't enough, she told me to also take Prilosec (otc). She told me that both work in different ways and are okay to take together. check with your doc about this-- it has made a huge difference for me!
Posts.Title: heartburn chk8 Irina

Posts.Content: Mar 17, 2011 06:20PM petjunkie wrote: Oh goodness! That's a lot to do only 48 hours after general anesthesia. I think it's pretty normal that you would feel exhausted and woozy after. But if the feeling continues even after you lay down and rest a few hours, you might want to call and let your doctor know. I have a friend that is an anesthesiologist and she told me that it varies depending on patient, drugs, etc., but not unusual for it to take up to a week to get all those drugs out of your system. Even if you feel like you're laying around doing nothing, you body is working hard to process the toxins and such. Drink lots of water and this as an excuse to watch TV or take a nap!
Posts.Title: Feeling Woozy After Surgery from Tuesday ScariedCat ScariedCat

Posts.Content: Mar 17, 2011 08:17PM petjunkie wrote: Yes! That dye is processed through the kidneys and comes out in the urine. They should have warned you about that, it is startling! Definitely take it easy and drink up. Especially if you are alone. Save the next outing for a time when someone can go with you, just in case you start to feel dizzy or anything.
Posts.Title: Feeling Woozy After Surgery from Tuesday ScariedCat ScariedCat

Posts.Content: Mar 9, 2011 12:22AM petjunkie wrote: The day I die, it won't be because I've given up. It won't be because i had a bad attitude one day or I lost hope or whatever. It will be because treatments stopped working and cancer cells took over my body and shut down my organs. I'm so tired of people taking about this positive attitude crap. Sorry, but patients are not responsible for their response to treatment. Thee are lots of great reasons to have a positive attitude and enjoy life each day. But anyone who tries to say that great women I've known have died because they gave up? Screw them. That's the most offensive junk I ever hear. I would have told that hairdresser to shove it. Sorry, reading that just made me so, so angry. Your friend needs to be in the best mental state that she can, and have support of family or friends, so she can get all the information she can and make an informed decision. Bone mets only is not a magic ticket to live 10+ years, it all depends on how resistant the cancer is to different treatments. Some women do very well and live a very long time with a good quality of life. Others do not. Her case will be individual and no one can predict how she will tolerate treatment or how much time it will give her. So she's got some tough choices ahead, as her friend it will help her a lot to have your support no matter what she decides to do.
Posts.Title: friend diagnosed, doesn't want treatment joy2011 petjunkie

Posts.Content: Nov 3, 2010 03:33AM petjunkie wrote: I'm so sorry about your sister. Do you know if her cancer is ER/PR positive, or Her2 positive? I am triple positive and had extensive liver mets when diagnosed with recurrence one year ago. I had never done chemo but had been on Tamoxifen for two years. I did 8 months of Taxol, Herceptin, and Zometa. The Zometa was for bone mets. The Taxol kicked butt. I started showing some progression after those 8 months, so we tried Femara and it didn't work. Right now I am on Herceptin and Tykerb. Two months of Tykerb and my liver mets are gone. There are lots of other ladies on here who will chime in with other treatments, I'm sure. You never know what might work for your sister, she will hopefully have a lot of options. One of the best things about the liver is that it does regenerate. If you can kill off the cancer, those mets spots can heal. Hope your appointment with the oncologist goes well and your sister can get whatever she needs-- she's lucky to have you fighting with her!
Posts.Title: Ladies please help re liver mets and treatments list Joannan nancyh

Posts.Content: Apr 27, 2011 05:32AM petjunkie wrote: SUV values are between 1-15. There are many reasons that bone will uptake the radioactive solution, so it doesn't always mean mets. I think the spine is especially confusing since arthritis and degenerative disk disease and all that can light up with SUV, too. If you are concerned, I wonder if you could ask for a second radiologist to review the scan and write a second report?

I would have continued, but it stopped working for me. At some point, the cancer figures out how to mutate.  But at Stage IV, I might have been getting a lower dose because the plan was to do it for so long? I never asked how my dose compared to others. And I still had all the side effects, lost my hair, etc.

Posts.Title: In a teeny funk CoolBreeze pejkug3

Posts.Content: Apr 12, 2014 01:54PM petjunkie wrote: I don't know specifically about returning to tamoxifen, but blood clots become a very common problem for people in long-term chemo. I've been on tamoxifen and femara (both failed), taxol, xeloda, tykerb, herceptin, navelbine, and now kadcycla. I've had a dvt and a pulmonary embolism, was on fragmin injections for about 6 months, then warfarin ever since. I was never taken off chemo during this time. My doctor explained that over time, chemotherapy damages blood cells. I also now have amenia and it's not from not getting enough iron, it's that my blood just can't store it the way it used to. So, blood clots are not unique to just tamoxifen treatment. If the tamoxifen was working for you friend, it would think it possible to go back as long as she was on blood thinners. However, once they shut her ovaries down with faslodex she would be taking drugs for post-menopausal women (tamoxifen is generally for pre-menopausal women).  I would question why her doctor is taking her off Tamoxifen while she is taking warfarin. Is there some kind of drug interaction? Most cancer patients who have had a DVT or PE stay on warfarin forever. If I were her, I would not want to be off Tamoxifen or any cancer treatment for 6 months, that seems like a long break. But if she brings it up with her doc, I'm sure there is a good explanation? or if not, she might want a second opinion. Karen
Posts.Title: Did you have mets, then Tamox., then clots, ...then what??? elimar Tomboy

Posts.Content: Apr 6, 2012 03:45PM petjunkie wrote: Hi, Sorry you have to go through this. Personally, I find PET scans easier than MRIs. I get them every 2-4 months, depending on how I'm responding to treatments, so I've had a lot of them. It's probably a little different at different facilities, but this is my experience. I do a PET/CT scan combo, so have to drink the barium stuff. You may not have to do that. When I arrive at the center they put me in my own room. I should mention that for prep i can have only water 12 hours before the test. No exercise for 48 hours before. They used to ask me to do a low carb/high protein diet the day before, but they no longer do that. Anyway, first thing is they put in an IV. I have a power port, but they don't use it for PETs, something about the speed of the tracer. I start to drink the barium and they take some vials of blood and they check my glucose level. Then, a tech from nuclear medicine comes in and injects a radioactive tracer through the IV. It is not at all painful. Then, I have to stay completely still in the reclining chair for 45 minutes. They don't even want me to read because they don't want eye movements picking up tracer. I can listen to music on my ipod. I find it very, very boring. When they come get me to walk me back to the machine, I stop off to pee because they want your bladder empty so they can see everything better. I lay on the narrow table with my hands above my head. It's like a donut around the table, not fully enclosed like an MRI. I don't have any anxiety or claustrophobia about the machine, while an MRI makes me very anxious. The scan takes about 30-40 minutes total, I just have to stay still. The table moves back and forth through the donut. It makes a whirring sound, but not loud banging like an MRI. The last few minutes of my scan, they inject a contrast through the IV and do the CT part-- it's the same machine. Because some people have allergic reactions to that contrast, they ask me to stay in the waiting area 15-20 minutes after the scan to make sure I don't show any signs of that. They have juice and snacks, which are nice after fasting for so long. That's it-- there is nothing painful other than getting the IV put in. I usually take ativan before I go in now just because I do these tests so often and I find it so tedious to be still for so long. Sometimes I'm more relaxed than others-- if we suspect a chemo has stopped working and I have progression, I am more anxious and find it awful to lay in that chair and then on that table without any real distraction. Sometimes I have discomfort like back pain for laying on that table so long-- ask for a pillow for under your knees and anything else you think might help with that. My PET scans are sent to the radiologist, who usually takes about a day to get the report to my onc. I meet with her 1-2 days after my scan to get results. The scan will show areas of "uptake" which can indicate several things, but a good radiologist should be able to tell if any of these are areas they think are mets. My PET scans show mets in my bones and liver. It will pick up other things-- fibroids in my uterus, gigivitis in my gums, etc. I know how nerve-wracking this testing can be. But PET scans are really good-- super expensive, so many people have to rely on just CTs.  Sounds like your new surgeon is giving you excellent care. I hope you get great results and that they can find an easy way to releive your pain.
Posts.Title: Please help, PET scan question dreidteacher jennyboog

Posts.Content: Feb 22, 2011 07:39PM petjunkie wrote: I did not have a PET scan when first diagnosed with DCIS. I had a mammogram, ultrasound, and breast MRI, but no PET or CT or bone scan.  My recurrence was found during my routine yearly exams because of tumor markers. This is what freaks me out-- my tumor markers were up in a crazy way (one that is supposed to be 0-37 was above 1500). The lymph nodes under my right arm (side of mastectomy) we a little enlarged. So they did a biopsy on them, and it was clean. The radiologist sent me home, oh you're fine! My oncologist didn't feel good about those tumor marker numbers, which had always been in normal limits for me before, so she fought my insurance company to get be a bone scan. Numerous mets on that scan got them to approve a PET scan. I keep thinking about leaving the cancer center after that biopsy, thinking everything was fine. How much longer might the cancer have spread through my body before it was found? If my onc hadn't trusted her instincts and fought for that scan, it could have gotten a lot worse before I got into treatment. I didn't have any symptoms besides fatigue. And I had just started a new job that had me traveling Mon-Fri, so who wouldn't attribute fatigue to that? I feel very lucky to have caught this. Even catching it sooner rather than later, I had bone mets on 17 different sites and more than 10 mets in my liver, some as large as 4cm and 5cm. This cancer was serious, but so far treatment is beating it back!
Posts.Title: DCIS to Stave IV with nothing between JMEH31854 ibcmets

Posts.Content: Mar 17, 2014 11:13PM petjunkie wrote: Hi All, I've had a year on TDM-1 now and am still going! This is the longest a treatment has ever worked for me. I have not had any regression, still bone mets and mets to liver, but everything has held stable and that's good enough for me. I did get a brain met during the last year, but gamma knife zapped it. The side effects of TDM-1 have continued to lessen with every round. I now have significant fatigue the weekend after infusion, achiness and no appetite, but that's about it. Cburke you should ask your doctor again about continuing Herceptin. Kadcycla is a chemo bound to Herceptin, so it's not typical to continue Herceptin during this treatment-- you are already getting it within Kadcycla. Hope this drug works great for you! Karen

But there are lots of women that do the fertility treatments before/after chemo and I know there are discussions about it in other areas of these boards. They can probably give you some advice and insight, though your oncologist will know what is best for your specific situation. Lots of gals here in the Stage IV forum are raising kids, though, so I'm sure some will chime in about the challenges of doing that during treatment (there is no "after treatments" for us). I only have fur babies. You might also check on the boards for the YSC, lots of women there under 40 thus maybe more folks in your situation with experience having kids while dealing with mets. Good luck to you!

Posts.Content: Feb 23, 2012 11:41AM petjunkie wrote: I had a unilateral mastectomy for DCIS about four years ago (my tumor was too large for a lumpectomy). My surgeon was Christine Calhoun and my onc is Julie Gralow (both at SCCA). Love my care at SCCA. Unfortunately I had a recurrence two years later and am now stage IV. Not to scare you about that, it was very rare. But just so I can tell you that i continue to be treated at SCCA and feel very lucky about that. I don't know what you age is, but I found a lot of support through the Young Survivor Coalition. They have a support group that meets at Gilda's House on Capitol Hill every other week. Generally, it's women diagnosed before they were 40, but the ages really do range from about 25-50.  It's a fun group of women and you'd get lots of support and information.

They have blankets, but I'm always thankful that I've worn thick socks.
Posts.Title: Please help, PET scan question dreidteacher jennyboog

Posts.Content: Feb 22, 2011 11:56PM petjunkie wrote: So as far as I know, the standard of care for DCIS (at least in 2007, when I was first diagnosed), was either a mastectomy+tamoxifen OR lumpectomy+radiation+tamoxifen. Having radiation was something only for lumpectomies-- if they took the whole breast, there was no indication of benefit from radiation. Now, this standard may have changed over the past few years, but I have not heard that. Also, I live in the US-- maybe radiation is not standard here, but is in other countries?
Posts.Title: DCIS to Stave IV with nothing between JMEH31854 ibcmets

Posts.Content: Feb 23, 2011 06:47PM petjunkie wrote: Beesie, I know that you mean well and work very hard to educate people. But others can have opinions here and express them here and it's really not your place to tell them to go elsewhere. If you'd like to have a discussion about DCIS in that forum, please do so. But the OP posted a valid question here and I am stage IV and have no problem discussing it here. The only thing that makes me uncomfortable is how at times your posts set a tone that you are right about everything and the rest of us are wrong. I just don't think it's that simple. I'm sure you feel you are always in the right. So fine, write what you want, but let the rest of us continue our discussion. My 2mm of IDC that was found in a first biopsy was never seen again-- and the pathologist sliced frozen sections of my entire breast three different times because they were so concerned that they were missing something after my mastectomy. My breast surgeon and my oncologists, both at UW and Seattle Cancer Care Alliance, agreed along with the rest of my tumor board team that I was Stage 0. If the microinvasion (which they called it, not a stage 1 tumor) had been in a lymph node they would have felt differently, i'm sure. But because it was placed in the middle of 9cm of DCIS, no one on the team thought it was possible that it was IDC that could have spread. They still considered my cancer a non-invasive stage 0. You can argue about this and tell me that my doctors and I are wrong. I trust them and if you disagree or if there are other ways to describe this now, that's just fine. I'm talking about MY EXPERIENCE here. And MY EXPERIENCE was that in 2007 I had a mastectomy and was told it was all DCIS, the biopsy IDC would be considered a microinvasion, that I was Stage 0 and would be put on tamoixfen for 5 years. My oncologist is Dr. Julie Gralow and I quite literally put my life in her hands. She is not stupid and neither am I. I understand the staging of breast cancer, and my team had reasons for making the decision that mine was a stage 0 cancer and not a stage 1. You write, "For all of the DCIS women who've popped into this thread, you are getting frightened for no reason."    I disagree.  I think it was pure luck that my biopsy caught that spot and if it hadn't, we would never have known about it. I think there are women out there that are told they have pure DCIS, and in rare cases they later have mets. There is no reason for women to be frightened, but if what they take away from my story is to keep vigilant and keep going for your mammograms and MRIs, then I think that's great.
Posts.Title: DCIS to Stave IV with nothing between JMEH31854 ibcmets

Posts.Content: Feb 10, 2010 04:05PM petjunkie wrote: Definitely call your doctor today. I got an infection through my port and it was so bad, even after I'd been on oral antibiotics for 5 days, that the infection got in my bloodstream. I was sick sick sick and had to be in the hospital for five days on IV antibiotics, have the port removed, and continue IV antibiotics at home through a PICC line for another two weeks. The fever and pain from a blood infection was the worst thing I'd ever experienced in my life. Get that port removed if you need to and keep yourself safe!
Posts.Title: Port infection? nancyh LiniWD

Posts.Content: Jun 24, 2013 06:08PM petjunkie wrote: I am 38, single, no kids. I do have really great support from my parents, who are in their early 70s and in good health. While I'm glad I don't have to worry about putting a spouse through this or having to worry about what a spouse is feeling, it can be difficult to be alone. It can get lonely sometimes. Selfishly, I sometimes get jealous of friends who have someone to share everything with. Just for one night, it would be lovely to have someone hold me while I slept. But then I am reminded of how much easier it is to deal with this alone. I can do whatever I want. I can sleep all day if I want to, I don't have to take care of anyone else. No one else has to see all of the side effects. I'm a private person in that way. And, I can sleep with all my pillows and my dogs on the bed and no one is here to complain!
Posts.Title: Anyone single and doing this cancer business ? diana50 gonegirl

Posts.Content: Feb 23, 2011 01:24PM petjunkie wrote: Oh this is one reason I hate sharing my story-- I don't want to freak anyone out! I go to a support group and for women who are there just diagnosed, still in shock, my story is their worst nightmare. It's so rare and random for this to happen, please don't let it worry you so much that it makes you miserable. I was never concerned about recurrence, really was not at all in my mind. But I am glad that I was vigilant about keeping up with my follow-up care, taking my tamoxifen and going to appointments. And because I was only 33 at diagnosis, I do think my doctors followed me more closely. My DCIS was grade 3 and triple positive, and combined with a young age it did indicate a more aggressive cancer. Anyway, thanks to everyone for the support. The info about radiation is interesting-- if I were diagnosed today, I might have been offered radiation as an option. But I never go back and second-guess my original treatments. I have a world-class oncologist and an awesome cancer center and I know that we made the best decisions we could at the time with the info given. And I'm getting outstanding treatment now, too-- I plan to be around for many, many years.
Posts.Title: DCIS to Stave IV with nothing between JMEH31854 ibcmets

Posts.Content: Feb 22, 2011 05:51PM petjunkie wrote: I had a similar situation. Diagnosed with DCIS, 9cm, in 2007. I had a mastectomy and in the pathology they found NOTHING-- there was originally one little invasive spot in a biopsy, but the biopsy got it all. So there was 2mm microinvasion in the middle of a 9cm DCIS. I was thrilled-- no radiation, no chemo, they just put me on tamoxifen. I had done a SNB and the nodes were clear. They called it Stage 0. Two years later I had a recurrence. There is still no cancer in the other breast or in my lymph nodes. But there were mets all over in my bones and my liver. My onc believes that my cancer must have spread through the blood vessels in the chest wall, since it's still not in the nodes. The doctors all still shake their heads, wondering how in the world this happened. But it did. So when I was diagnosed stage IV in Oct 2010, that was my first time facing chemo. Definitely a shock!
Posts.Title: DCIS to Stave IV with nothing between JMEH31854 ibcmets

Posts.Content: Feb 23, 2011 12:12AM petjunkie wrote: xmasdx, Tumor markers are usually reactive proteins that are found in bloodwork. It's still a bit controversial-- some people can have terrible cancer through their bodies and their markers are fine. There are many oncologists who do not check markers because they don't believe they are accurate in enough women to make it worth doing-- many docs think they cause unnecessary worry. In my particular case, tumor markers have be very accurate at showing cancer progression. I could have these a little wrong but there are 2 we check, the CA 27-29 and the CEA. I can't remember which is which. . . one is supposed to be 0-37, another one is supposed to be 0-5. Mine were something like 1560 and 210 when first diagnosed with mets. We've tracked them through all my treatments and they go down when chemo is working, they raise when my cancer progresses. I feel very lucky to have these quick, easy little blood tests that give me a little window into how things are going. If you do a search on these boards, you'll find other discussions about tumor markers-- good and bad. But something to ask your oncologist about, for sure.
Posts.Title: DCIS to Stave IV with nothing between JMEH31854 ibcmets

Posts.Content: May 14, 2012 09:46PM petjunkie wrote: In so many ways I feel grateful that I don't have kids or a husband-- I don't have to worry about leaving them behind. But I also feel like I was cheated out of so many things. Stage IV at 35, I had to quit my job (it involved a lot of travel). I will never build a career, I will never get married, I will never have kids. I feel really bad for my mom, who would have loved to be a grandma. My friends are young and just starting their families. Some say stupid things. I know they mean well, but "you're so lucky you don't have to work" isn't helpful. Luckily they don't try to tell me that they know how I feel. But women in my support group do and it makes me feel really alienated from the group. I'm either their worst nightmare and have to listen to them talk about how afraid they are of getting mets, or they talk about how hard it is to "be a survivor" and "move on from cancer." I know they face their own challenges, I do. But in the moment sometimes it's hard to be understanding. What I would give to have to move on with my life and worry only about a possible recurrance!
Posts.Title: No, you don't understand... Stormynyte Reneepals

Posts.Content: Jan 10, 2011 08:51PM petjunkie wrote: I have liver mets, but have never had any pain from them. Is there any chance that this pain you have gets worse at night, or after eating? It seems like quite a few women have had gallbladder attacks, and the pain is in that area. I hope some others will chime in to help you here. I'm mad at your Onc-- they should never leave pain unaddressed. You have the RIGHT to good pain management, and whatever it takes to get to the bottom of it.
Posts.Title: rib pain or is it liver pain? Honeybear Marybetz
